content.question: Element <math alttext="N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></math> <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></math> <math alttext="A s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>As</mtext></mrow></math> <math alttext="S b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Sb</mtext></mrow></math> <math alttext="B i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Bi</mtext></mrow></math> Atomic Radius (picometers) <math alttext="65" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>65</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="115" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>115</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="145" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>145</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="160" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>160</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> The atomic radii of the elements in the nitrogen group in the periodic table are given in the table above. Which of the following best helps explain the trend of increasing atomic radius from <math alttext="N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow></math> to <math alttext="B i" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Bi</mtext></mrow></math>?

choices.label: The number of particles in the nucleus of the atom increases.
The number of electrons in the outermost shell of the atom increases.
The attractive force between the valence electrons and the nuclei of the atoms decreases.
The repulsive force between the valence electrons and the electrons in the inner shells decreases.

content.answer: The attractive force between the valence electrons and the nuclei of the atoms decreases.
